ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SILKAIR M1 185 CRASH

(Latest report)



    1. Mr Sin Boon Ann asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology whether the authority will now review its requirements and pay closer attention to pilots in the light of the recent revelation by the investigators of the SilkAir MI 185 crash.

    2. Mr Chuang Shaw Peng asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology whether he will give a

Column: 2266

latest report on the details of the crash of SilkAir MI 185.

    3. Mr Shriniwas Rai asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology if he will tell the House what steps the Government and Singapore Airlines intend to take regarding the SilkAir accident.

    The Minister for Communications and Information Technology (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, may I have your permission to take the first three Questions together?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, in accordance with international practice, the investigations into the crash of SilkAir Flight MI 185 are led by Indonesia, the state of occurrence of the crash. They are being conducted by a competent and independent team of professional air accident investigators. The investigators are from Indonesia, Singapore, the US and Australia. They have access to the best investigation facilities, laboratories and expertise in these countries. The Aircraft Accident Investigation Commission has been constituted according to well-established practices laid down by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO).

    In carrying out its investigation, this multi-national team is looking into all relevant aspects in a systematic and holistic manner. This includes investigating the human factor. In fact, a sub-group of the investigation team is specifically tasked with that responsibility. Members of this sub-group include pilots, psychologists, a psychiatrist, and a medical doctor. The investigation team has access to relevant information on human factors in Singapore as well as other countries.

    In addition, the team has also been looking into the relevant operational procedures of SilkAir and will certainly report on any shortcomings.

    Upon completion of its investigations, the investigation team will submit its final

Column: 2267

report to ICAO and concerned states. ICAO will study the recommendations and propose improvements where applicable. Singapore would certainly adopt any ICAO recommendation to enhance aviation safety.

Singapore Police Investigation

    As the House is aware, the Indonesian Minister of Communications, Mr Giri Hadihardjono, informed me on 25th August 1999 that the team investigating the SilkAir Flight MI 185 accident has found indications raising suspicions that unlawful interference may have been a factor in the accident. Based on this suspicion, the Singapore Government has referred the matter to the Singapore Police. The Police is conducting a separate police investigation into the matter in consultation with the Public Prosecutor to ascertain if there is evidence of any criminal offence. I can assure Members that the Police will be thorough and professional and will also examine all the relevant details, including the financial records.

    We should therefore await the findings of the Accident Investigation Team and the Police Investigation, especially since the Accident Investigation Team is now in the final stages of its investigations. There is no necessity to appoint another inquiry into the matter, and we should not complicate matters by doing so.

Aviation Standards and Procedures

    Mr Sin Boon Ann has asked whether the authority will review its pilot requirements in the light of the recent findings. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore or CAAS ensures that our aviation regulations and operational procedures of our airlines conform fully to international norms stipulated by ICAO. As such, the CAAS continuously monitors and reviews the flight operations and engineering procedures of both SilkAir and SIA.

    Both pilots of MI 185 satisfied the licensing requirements based on international norms stipulated by ICAO. CAAS has also looked into the three disciplinary

Column: 2268

cases involving the pilot, Captain Tsu Way Ming. CAAS is satisfied that the safety of the aircraft or persons on board was never compromised in each case, and that there was no reason for SilkAir to ground Captain Tsu.

    Moreover, the interim update confirms that "both pilots were properly trained, licensed, and qualified to conduct the flight." In fact, the Airline Pilots Association of Singapore has issued a statement on 29th August 1999 to say that "In our professional opinion, these (3) incidents, when viewed singularly or collectively do not constitute operational or performance-related incompetence."

    Our airlines also benchmark their standards against that of international airlines in leading aviation countries to ensure that they are in line with ICAO guidelines and international best practice. Nonetheless, we cannot be complacent. We will continue to review and upgrade our aviation standards and procedures as the best international practices evolve.

    In conclusion, let me state that the Government fully appreciates the anguish of the next-of-kins and their anxiety to learn the cause of the MI 185 crash. While the investigation team has made further progress, it has yet to establish the cause of the accident. The team needs to carry out further work to analyse the facts and findings before it can conclude the investigation. The Government will continue to participate actively in the investigations and will extend our fullest co-operation to the investigation team.

    Mr Chay Wai Chuen (Tanjong Pagar): Will the Minister be able to tell us whether there is any coroner's inquiry in Singapore on this matter?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, we have sought the advice of the Attorney-General and we have been advised that in this case, the coroner has no jurisdiction because under the Criminal Procedure Code, he can only inquire into the death of a person or the finding of a dead body in suspicious circumstances in Singapore

Column: 2269

and which is within the territorial jurisdiction of the coroner. In the present case, the death occurred in Palembang, Indonesia when the aircraft crashed into the River Musi. The remains of the passengers and crew were also buried there and therefore it is not possible for the coroner's inquiry to be conducted here.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Will the Minister be able to tell us when were the personal problems of the pilot, which have now been revealed, disclosed to the investigators?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, I understand the Aircraft Accident Investigation Commission made enquiries shortly after the crash and all the information were given within a month of the crash.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): May I ask the Minister if there is a need for psycho-analytical assessments for pilots on a regular basis as part of their routine medical check-ups?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, I understand that the mental health of the pilots is also examined as part of their regular check-ups.

NET INVESTMENT INCOME


    4. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for Finance, since Net Investment Income (NII) is considered as part of current reserves, whether governments can run budget deficits up to the magnitude of NII (which has been about S$3-5 billion a year) for that year, without drawing on past reserves.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Sir, as all NII is current reserves under the Constitution, the government of the day can use NII to fund deficits and can run budget deficits up to the magnitude of the NII without drawing on past reserves. However, this Government has not had to fall back on NII at all for any

Column: 2270

purpose, as it had accumulated sufficient budget surpluses within its current term of office.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Sir, will the Minister consider a review of the NII? Instead of allowing for the full portion to be put into current reserves, limit a certain portion of it into current reserves, since NII is accrued from past reserves.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I believe I have said in an earlier sitting of Parliament that we are considering the possibility of locking up part of NII, and we are studying this possibility. If we should decide to do so, there will be a change to the Constitution next year.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: The Minister says that investment income forms part of the current reserves because they are provided for in the Constitution. Would he be good enough to draw us to the Article or provision in the Constitution which says this.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I suggest he looks it up himself.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): The Minister stated that he would consider changing the Constitution in order to define NII or the part of NII that goes to current or past reserves. Would the Minister also consider at the same time changing the Constitution in order to incorporate the definition of past reserves in the Constitution?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: NII is defined in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. These Principles are well established and used universally not only in Singapore but in many other jurisdictions. So the question of the definition is not difficult.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Clarification, Minister. I think my question was really regarding the last part of your comment which said that you would change the Constitution in order to state whether what part of NII would belong to past reserves and to current reserves. Perhaps I was wrong in this matter.

Column: 2271



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: What we meant was we would try and decide what portion of NII should be locked up, however we define it.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: As I see it, Minister, if the change of the Constitution is to define the portion of NII that belongs to past reserves, then would the Minister also consider at the same time including in the Constitution the definition of "reserves" that was stated in the White Paper? Because right now it is not in the Constitution.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I am sure we would do whatever is necessary.

SINGAPORE POLICE FORCE

(Corruption cases)



    5. Mr Sin Boon Ann asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether there has been an increase in recent years in the number of corruption cases within the Police Force and, if so, what steps have been taken to solve the problem.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, there is no upward trend in the number of corruption cases within the Police Force in recent years.

    As at 31st August this year, there were five corruption cases where 10 officers were charged in court as compared to six cases (involving eight officers) in 1998, three cases (involving three officers) in 1997, eight cases (involving nine officers) in 1996 and three cases (involving three officers) in 1995.

    The number of Police officers charged in court for corruption averaged about 5.75 per year from 1995 to 1998. This makes up less than 0.08% of the Police Force strength.

    The Commissioner of Police has given the assurance that corrupt officers will be systematically weeded-out. They will be held fully accountable for their actions even if it means having to make their acts

Column: 2272

public. Such transparency clearly demonstrates SPF's determination to eradicate corruption. We will not allow public confidence in the Police to be eroded because of the acts of a few rogue officers.

    Indeed, the Police has implemented a range of enhanced measures aimed at eradicating corruption and criminal acts in the Force. These include:

    First, more effective preventive measures;

    Second, stronger detection mechanisms; and

    Third, proactive co-operation with CPIB.

    Sir, the Police is fully conscious of the trust and respect accorded to them by the public. The exemplary conduct and behaviour of officers contribute to this trust and respect. We will continue to uphold the high standards and values that we have set for our police officers.

Column: 2272

SPEED LIMIT ON EXPRESSWAYS



    6. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will consider raising the speed limit on expressways.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, Police and LTA regularly review speed limits on our roads and expressways. In June last year, the speed limits of nine roads were raised from 50 kmh to 60 kmh. The speed limit of 10 more roads will similarly be raised to 60 kmh in October this year.

    Sir, over the years, there have been improvements made to a number of roads and expressways and also to vehicle engineering. Some of the expressways can therefore accommodate vehicles travelling at higher speeds. Traffic Police and LTA have conducted a preliminary study of the eight expressways. The studies indicate that various stretches of our expressways can support a safe speed of 90 kmh. We have therefore decided to raise the speed limit of two stretches of expressways from 80 kmh to 90 kmh. After three months, if drivers' behaviour,

Column: 2273

traffic situation and accident rates are satisfactory, we can extend the higher speed limit to other expressways.

    Sir, the two expressways where the speed limits will be raised from 80 kmh to 90 kmh from October this year are the East Coast Parkway (ECP) from Benjamin Sheares Bridge to Changi Airport, and the Kranji Expressway (KJE).

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, will the Minister of State also consider taking action against slow moving traffic on the overtaking lanes?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: I think the Member is referring to road hogging. Sir, road hogging is an offence in Singapore. But Traffic Police tells me that it is not a serious problem. Indeed, offenders who have been apprehended have come down. In 1995, there were 1,200 and last year, there were 600. But I would agree with the Member that there is a continuous need for education and also continuous enforcement because this way, our expressways will flow even more smoothly.

    Mr R. Ravindran (Bukit Timah): In the light of the fact that traffic is light during off peak hours between 10 pm and 6 am, would the Ministry also consider increasing the speed limit on the expressways during the off peak hours to, say, 100 kmh?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the fact that traffic is light and you are all alone on the road or you are with few cars may in fact lull you into a sense of complacency. Indeed, cars that go at excessive speeds at these times have resulted in very serious accidents. We should leave it as that. We will monitor the situation. By bringing up to 90 kmh, it is still within the safe limit. That is important.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD

(Review of planning methodology)



    7. Mr R Ravindran asked the Minister for National Development whether his

Column: 2274

Ministry will review existing Housing and Development Board (HDB) planning methodology and consider new measures to better co-ordinate the timely provision of various facilities and services in new HDB estates.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government's objective is to make every new HDB town as self-sufficient as possible. In addition to building new HDB flats, HDB also carries out comprehensive town planning for new HDB towns. It safeguards lands for a host of commercial, educational, social, recreational/sports, religious and institutional facilities based on planning norms and guidelines provided by the relevant authorities. The planning norms are reviewed regularly to take into account the changing profile of residents.

    Commercial facilities are built in tandem with the completion of flats to cater to residents' needs. Each town is planned with a town centre, which is developed by the private sector. It will also have neighbourhood centres which will serve a neighbourhood of between 6,000 and 8,000 households. At the precinct level, HDB will also provide some shops to serve the daily needs of residents. It will, as far as possible, locate these shops within walking distance of the residents' flats.

    All these facilities have to be built in stages in tandem with the increasing catchment of the new towns in order to maximise the use of the facilities. While it is feasible for HDB to build the facilities in advance, the shopkeepers are unlikely to commence operation before sufficient residents have moved in as their business would not be viable.

FORMER PRESIDENTS

(Financial and personnel support)



    8. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Prime Minister whether former Presidents are entitled to some form of financial and personnel support from the Government in order to maintain the dignity and

Column: 2275

stature of their former office; and in particular, whether they receive (i) a pension; (ii) medical benefits; (iii) secretarial support; and (iv) a small office.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Constitution does not provide for former Presidents automatically to receive pension and medical benefits. However, the Civil List and Pension Act provide for any person who ceases to be President to be granted a pension for such amount and on such terms as Parliament may, by resolution, determine. In determining the terms for granting a pension to a former President, Parliament may also decide to accord him post-retirement medical benefits.

    In the past, Parliament had passed a resolution granting a pension of $2,000 per month to the widow of the late Mr Yusof bin Ishak and $500 per annum jointly to his two children until the younger child attains the age of 21 years. As a pensioner, the widow is also receiving medical benefits.

    Parliament had also passed a resolution granting Mr Devan Nair a pension of $5,000 per month on condition that he continued to receive, and abide by, such medical advice and treatment as may be prescribed for him by a panel of doctors. Mr Nair declined the pension.

    No provisions for pension were made for the widow of Mr Benjamin Sheares, and for Mr Wee Kim Wee. The Prime Minister, however, had approved as a special case, medical benefits for Mr Wee and his wife.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong will not be receiving any pension as a former President. However, he is receiving pension as a former office-holding Member of Parliament. As for medical benefits, he will continue to be on the Medisave-cum-Subsidised Outpatient (MSO) Scheme.

    Former Presidents are not provided with secretarial support or an office as they cease to perform any official function when they step down.

Column: 2276



    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: May I ask the Prime Minister whether it is possible now for Parliament to approve a pension for the former President, Mr Wee?

    Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, when we decided on not giving pension to former Presidents, it was with a view of not putting unnecessary pressure on the budget or strain on taxpayers. We normally look for somebody who has retired or is about to retire to become the President, and normally, such person would have some savings of his own. And as the President, the pay would not be insubstantial. So we decided not to have pension for former Presidents. This would also apply to Mr Wee.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Would the Prime Minister consider to err on the generous side because I think former Presidents are under some obligation to maintain the dignity and stature of the office.

    Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I explained, the pay of a President is not insubstantial and the dignity of a former President does not depend on his financial wealth. It depends very much on how the former President carries himself.

MALAY HERITAGE COMMITTEE

(Government assistance)


    9. Mr Harun A Ghani asked the Minister for Information and the Arts to what extent the Government will assist the Malay Heritage Committee other than providing the $2 million grant.

    The Minister for Information and the Arts (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Malay Heritage Centre is a Malay community project owned and led by the Malay community, with Government's assistance during the initial planning stage. Besides a matching grant of up to $2 million which will go towards an Endowment Fund, the Government will bear the full restoration cost of the former Istana Kg Glam and Gedung Kuning - the neighbouring building - also known as Bendahara House.

SCHOOL DROP-OUTS



    10. Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh asked the Minister for Education (a) how many students dropped out of the education chain in 1998 and the first half of 1999; (b) what is the profile of the school leavers; (c) what measures are being undertaken to keep them in school; (d) among the 5,640 students who dropped out between 1995 and 1997, how many had been counselled and allowed to return to schools; and (e) whether there was any attempt to reach the rest of the drop-outs to monitor their educational and personal development.

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of students who drop out of our schools has been on a downward trend over the years. At the primary level, the number of such students decreased from 1,022 or 2.6% of the Primary 1 cohort in 1988, to 183 or 0.4% in 1998. So that was the difference over those 10 years, from 2.6% of cohort in 1988 to 0.4% of cohort in 1998. That is the drop-out rate from primary schools. At the secondary level, it decreased from 1,844 or 4.3% of the Primary 1 cohort to 1,400 or 3.5% over the same period of time. The figures for the first 8 months of 1999 was 114 or 0.2% of the Primary 1 cohort at the primary level, and 612 or 1.6% of the Primary 1 cohort at the secondary level. The Member asked for the profile of the school leavers. More than half of the students who left at the primary level were Primary 6 students, while a third of those who left at the secondary level were in Secondary 3.

    Sir, when students show signs of dropping out, principals and teachers strenuously try to dissuade them from doing so. Their efforts include counselling the students, monitoring their attendance rate and contacting their homes when

Column: 2278

they are absent, inviting the parents to school, and making home visits to discuss the matter with the parents. In some cases, school inspectors, cluster superintendents and educational psychologists are also involved in the counselling process. Where the reason for dropping out is financial, schools are prepared to extend financial aid to the students like our various community organisations.
